item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Cherie Blair
item.description: Mrs. Blair on Indian women who inspire her and what she learns from them.
item.dc:creator: By HARESH PANDYA
item.media:description: Cherie Blair, center, during her visit to the Rural Distribution Network India center at Kuda village in Gujarat on March 19, 2013.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: ‘Occupy’ Hong Kong, for Universal Suffrage
item.description: As some in Hong Kong deal with growing dissatisfaction over the city’s restrictive political arrangements under China, others are planning for a more aggressive Occupy movement to push for full democracy by 2017.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: People protest near the Hong Kong government's headquarters last year against plans to align the city more closely with mainland China through education. Universal suffrage is also a common theme in demonstrations in Hong Kong.

item.title: India Ink: Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, Screenwriter, Dies at 85
item.description: The German-born screenwriter and novelist who married an Indian architect was a member of the Merchant Ivory film-making team.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: Where YouTube Meets the Farm
item.description: Bringing knowledge to farmers through locally produced videos could help promote better agricultural practices.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: As North Korea Seals Border, U.S. Bolsters Defenses
item.description: The North’s threats and provocative acts prompted the Pentagon to announce the deployment of an advanced radar battery and antimissile system to Guam.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Trucks from South Korea were turned back after being banned from entering a jointly operated industrial park in Kaesong, North Korea, on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: Becoming a Female Police Officer in Delhi: Do You Qualify?
item.description: As Delhi’s police force recruits thousands of women, a look at what it takes to get hired.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: Moscow Tries to Remake Itself as Financial Center
item.description: Long known as a difficult place to do business, Moscow is making a major effort to encourage banks, insurance companies and law firms that deal with securities to expand there.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moscow is betting on new skyscrapers to attract foreign banks and help it overcome a reputation as a difficult place to do business.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Reward Offered for Information on Kony
item.description: The United States on Wednesday offered a reward of up to $5 million each for the fugitive Ugandan warlord Joseph Kony and some of his top aides in the Lord’s Resistance Army.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Regional Leaders Refuse to Recognize Rebel Head in Central African Republic
item.description: African heads of state on Wednesday refused to recognize the rebel leader Michel Djotodia’s self-appointment as president of Central African Republic.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Court Rules Against Extradition of Former Qaddafi Aide to Libya
item.description: An Egyptian court ruled Wednesday against the extradition to Libya of Ahmed Qaddaf al-Dam, a former close aide of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Court Sentences Guerrillas
item.description: A Greek court on Wednesday handed down 50-year prison sentences to three leading members of the guerrilla group Revolutionary Struggle.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Attacks on Elderly Armenian Turks Awaken Fears
item.description: The violence recalls a tortured past and, perhaps, hints at future tensions as Turkey prepares to face the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turfanda Asik, 88, was attacked and robbed in Samatya, the Armenian quarter of Istanbul. “He just beat me, over and over again,” she said.

item.title: Multiplying the Old Divisions of Class in Britain
item.description: Using an online questionnaire filled out by over 161,000 people, the BBC has concluded that in today’s complicated world, there are seven social classes, not three.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: From left: John Cleese, Ronnie Barker and Ronnie Corbett in a video still from a satirical British TV sketch illustrating class. And height.

item.title: Ahmadinejad of Iran Reshapes Image Ahead of June Vote
item.description: With only months to go before his last presidential term, and elections in June, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has surprised many of his critics by challenging a coalition of traditionalists.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Mohammad Hassanzadeh/Fars News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, left, with Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei, his chosen successor.

item.title: Princess Cristina of Spain Is Subpoenaed in Embezzlement Case
item.description: A judge subpoenaed Princess Cristina, the daughter of King Juan Carlos, as part of a widening investigation into whether her husband embezzled millions of euros from a sports charity.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Sheep Tend Lawn Outside City Archives in Paris
item.description: City officials call the 19th Arrondissement project “eco-grazing,” an alternative to noisy, gas-guzzling mowers and the use of herbicides.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Black sheep arrived for an "eco-grazing" project on a parcel of land in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Airports in China Hew to an Unswerving Flight Path
item.description: Terminal 2 at Hongqiao International Airport demonstrates China’s ability to move huge projects forward efficiently.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:credit: Jackson Lowen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Wujun, chief technical officer at the Shanghai Airport Authority and one of the main planners behind Terminal 2.

item.title: The Lede: U.S. Embassy in Cairo Scrubs Twitter Feed of Link to ‘Daily Show’ Commentary on Egypt
item.description: The U.S. Embassy in Cairo edited its official Twitter feed to remove an update that drew attention to video of the comedian Jon Stewart’s withering criticism of Egypt’s government.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and LIAM STACK
item.media:description: A screenshot of the official Twitter feed of United States Embassy in Cairo on Wednesday.

item.title: IHT Special : Despite Challenges, Banks Look to Set Up Branches in Iraq
item.description: The dominance of state-run banks and high costs for compliance and security are hurdles, but the country’s economy and oil reserves are proving irresistible.
item.dc:creator: By SARA HAMDAN

item.title: IHT Special: Northern Cyprus Sees Hope in Water Pipeline
item.description: An ambitious project would route water from Turkey using an experimental technology: a pipeline in the Mediterranean Sea.
item.dc:creator: By ERICA GIES

item.title: Irish Search for Billionaire’s Assets Leads to Russia
item.description: The Irish government hopes to seize a dozen properties in Russia and Ukraine belonging to Sean Quinn, a bankrupt Irish businessman who was once the country’s richest man.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Cork Journal: Dominican Friars Growing in Number
item.description: Even as other orders close houses and parish priests in Ireland are vanishing, the Dominican order, which has kept its ancient robes and communal lifestyle, is growing.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Rev. Gerard Dunne, second from left, and new priests talked to members of the public interested in joining the order.

item.title: Argentina’s Record Floods Kill Dozens
item.description: The deluge left thousands homeless and renewed tensions as politicians blamed one another for the high death toll.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: A soldier evacuates an elderly woman in a flooded street in La Plata, a provincial capital 30 miles from Buenos Aires.

item.title: IHT Special: Fall in Egyptian Pound Weighs Heavily on the Ill
item.description: A steep devaluation in the Egyptian pound, and the lack of hard currency, makes it harder to import expensive drugs because the law requires them to be resold at a fixed price.
item.dc:creator: By FARAH HALIME
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hospital workers waited for protesters injured during clashes with the police in the Egyptian city of Port Said in January.

item.title: I.M.F. and Europe Set Strict Terms for Cyprus
item.description: The head of the I.M.F. called the conditions of the bailout, which include budget cuts and privatization of state assets, “a challenging program.”
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the I.M.F., said the bailout plan will require "great efforts from the Cypriot population."
